title: Troy Aikman
text:
Troy Kenneth Aikman (born November 21, 1966) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> who played in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for 12 seasons with the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>. After transferring from <a href="University%20of%20Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, he won the <a href="Pac-12%20Conference%20football%20individual%20awards">Pac-10 Offensive Player of the Year</a> at <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Los%20Angeles">UCLA</a> and was selected <a href="List%20of%20first%20overall%20National%20Football%20League%20draft%20picks">first overall</a> by the Cowboys in the <a href="1989%20NFL%20Draft">1989 NFL Draft</a>. As the Cowboys' longest-tenured quarterback, Aikman received six <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> selections and won three <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> titles from 1992 to 1995. Aikman was named <a href="Super%20Bowl%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">MVP</a> of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXVII">Super Bowl XXVII</a>, the franchise's first in over a decade. He was inducted to the <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a> in 2006 and the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Football Hall of Fame</a> in 2008.
Since retiring in 2000, Aikman has served as a television <a href="sportscaster">sportscaster</a> for the <a href="NFL%20on%20Fox">Fox</a> network. Aikman was also a former joint owner of the <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> <a href="Sprint%20Cup%20Series">Sprint Cup Series</a> racing team <a href="Hall%20of%20Fame%20Racing">Hall of Fame Racing</a>, along with fellow former Cowboys quarterback <a href="Roger%20Staubach">Roger Staubach</a>, and was a part-owner of the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB).
Early life.
Aikman was born on November 21, 1966. He spent the first part of his childhood in <a href="West%20Covina%2C%20California">West Covina, California</a>. At the age of 12, Aikman's family moved to <a href="Henryetta%2C%20Oklahoma">Henryetta, Oklahoma</a>, where he played <a href="high%20school%20football">football</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a> at Henryetta High School, where he would earn All-State honors. Aikman also won the 1983 Oklahoma high school state championship in typing.
College career.
Oklahoma Sooners.
The <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> offered Aikman a contract out of high school, but instead of playing baseball he chose to pursue football and attended the <a href="University%20of%20Oklahoma">University of Oklahoma</a> under head coach <a href="Barry%20Switzer">Barry Switzer</a>.
In 1984, he became the first freshman to start at quarterback for Oklahoma since World War II. In 1985, his first full season as a collegiate starter, Aikman led the Sooners to victories over <a href="Minnesota%20Golden%20Gophers%20football">Minnesota</a>, <a href="Kansas%20State%20Wildcats%20football">Kansas State</a>, and #17 <a href="Texas%20Longhorns%20football">Texas</a> in the <a href="Red%20River%20Shootout">Red River Shootout</a> before losing to the <a href="Miami%20Hurricanes%20football">Miami Hurricanes</a> as he left the game with a broken ankle. He also lost to his future teammate, <a href="Michael%20Irvin">Michael Irvin</a> and future head coach, <a href="Jimmy%20Johnson%20%28American%20football%20coach%29">Jimmy Johnson</a>, who had also scouted him when he was the head coach of <a href="Oklahoma%20State%20Cowboys%20football">Oklahoma State</a>.
On October 19, Miami's <a href="Jerome%20Brown">Jerome Brown</a> broke through the offensive line, sacked Aikman on the Sooner 29-yard line and broke Aikman's ankle. Aikman, who had been six of eight passing for 131 yards, would be lost for the season. Switzer and offensive coordinator <a href="Jim%20Donnan">Jim Donnan</a> were forced to switch back to the <a href="wishbone%20formation">wishbone offense</a> under freshman quarterback <a href="Jamelle%20Holieway">Jamelle Holieway</a>. The team went on to win the <a href="1985%20Oklahoma%20Sooners%20football%20team">1985</a> <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">National Championship</a>. With Holieway established as the starting quarterback at OU, Aikman decided to transfer to UCLA.
UCLA Bruins.
<a href="Barry%20Switzer">Barry Switzer</a> oversaw Aikman's <a href="Transfer%20admissions%20in%20the%20United%20States">transfer</a> to <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Los%20Angeles">UCLA</a>, a program under <a href="Terry%20Donahue">Terry Donahue</a> that was more conducive to a passing quarterback. He had to sit out one year due to college transfer rules but went on to lead the Bruins to a 20–4 record over two seasons.
As a junior, Aikman earned the <a href="Pac-10%20Offensive%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Pac-10 Offensive Player of the Year</a>. He led the Bruins to a 10–2 record and the <a href="1987%20Aloha%20Bowl">1987 Aloha Bowl</a>, where they beat the <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida Gators</a> 20–16.
As a senior, Aikman won the 1988 <a href="Davey%20O%27Brien%20Award">Davey O'Brien Award</a> as the nation's top quarterback, a first for UCLA. He was a Consensus All-American, the UPI West Coast Player of the Year, the Washington DC Club QB of the Year, a finalist for the 1988 AFCA "Coaches Choice" Player of the year award, and finished third in voting for the 1988 <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a>. UCLA matched the victory total from the previous season under Aikman, going 10–2 and losing only to <a href="USC%20Trojans%20football">USC</a> and <a href="Washington%20State%20Cougars%20football">Washington State</a>. The <a href="1988%20UCLA%20Bruins%20football%20team">1988 season</a> culminated with a 17–3 Bruins victory over the <a href="Arkansas%20Razorbacks%20football">Arkansas Razorbacks</a> in the <a href="1989%20Cotton%20Bowl%20Classic">1989 Cotton Bowl Classic</a>, which was played in Dallas. The Dallas media spent most of the Cotton Bowl Classic week promoting Aikman as the "next quarterback of the Cowboys," and much was made of Cowboys head coach <a href="Tom%20Landry">Tom Landry</a> watching Aikman practice during the Bruins' workouts at <a href="Texas%20Stadium">Texas Stadium</a>. Aikman finished his career as the number two career passing leader in UCLA history.
In 2008, Aikman was elected to the College Football Hall of Fame. On November 28, 2014, UCLA retired his #8 jersey at halftime against <a href="Stanford%20Cardinal%20football">Stanford</a>.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Aikman was the first overall pick in the <a href="1989%20NFL%20Draft">1989 NFL Draft</a>, by the Dallas Cowboys. On February 25, 1989, new owner <a href="Jerry%20Jones">Jerry Jones</a> fired <a href="Tom%20Landry">Tom Landry</a> and replaced him with <a href="Jimmy%20Johnson%20%28American%20football%20coach%29">Jimmy Johnson</a>. A few months later, in the NFL's supplemental draft, Johnson drafted <a href="Steve%20Walsh%20%28American%20football%29">Steve Walsh</a>, who played for Johnson at the <a href="University%20of%20Miami">University of Miami</a>. Aikman won the starting quarterback job, and Walsh was traded early in the 1990 season.
Aikman played his first NFL preseason game on August 26, 1989 against the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a>. His NFL debut started with a 28–0 loss to the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>. The following week, Aikman threw his first touchdown pass, a 65-yard completion to <a href="Michael%20Irvin">Michael Irvin</a>, but the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a> intercepted two passes and won. In a game against the Arizona Cardinals, he threw for 379 yards to set an NFL rookie record. Aikman finished 1989 with a 0–11 record as a starter, completing 155 of 293 passes for 1,749 yards, 9 touchdowns, and 18 interceptions.
Following Aikman's rookie season, Dallas selected Florida Gators running back <a href="Emmitt%20Smith">Emmitt Smith</a> in the first round of the <a href="1990%20NFL%20Draft">1990 NFL Draft</a>. With Smith and Irvin, Aikman led the Cowboys to a 7–7 record in the 1990 season, but was injured in the 15th game, against the <a href="Philadelphia%20Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a>. The Cowboys would go on to lose that game and the following week against the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a> with backup quarterback <a href="Babe%20Laufenberg">Babe Laufenberg</a>, missing the final playoff wild card spot by one game.
In 1991, Aikman led the Cowboys to a 6–4 record in the first 10 games and had the Cowboys ahead in week 12 against undefeated <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> when he was injured. <a href="Steve%20Beuerlein">Steve Beuerlein</a> replaced Aikman, and Dallas finished the season 5–0 and earned the #5 playoff seed. Beuerlein went on to lead the Cowboys to a road upset over the #4 seed <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> in the Wild Card round. With the Cowboys trailing 17–6 at halftime the following week against the <a href="Detroit%20Lions">Detroit Lions</a> in the NFC Divisional Playoff game, Aikman was inserted to start the third quarter, but was unable to provide a spark as the Cowboys lost, 38–6. Aikman was selected to the first of six consecutive <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a>s.
In 1992, Aikman set career highs in completions (302), passing yards (3,445) and touchdown passes (23), and led the Cowboys to a team record 13 regular-season victories and the second-best record in the NFC. During the playoffs, Aikman broke Joe Montana's record of 83 passes without an interception by throwing 89. The Cowboys defeated the Eagles at home in the Division Playoffs and squared off against the 49ers in the NFC Championship, a matchup that featured the two best teams in the NFC. The Cowboys won, 30–20, with Aikman completing two game-changing passes to send the Cowboys to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1979. In <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXVII">Super Bowl XXVII</a> against the Buffalo Bills, Aikman led the Cowboys to a 52–17 victory (coincidentally the game was played in his alma mater's home stadium, the <a href="Rose%20Bowl%20%28stadium%29">Rose Bowl</a>). Aikman was named <a href="Super%20Bowl%20MVP">Super Bowl MVP</a> after completing 22-of-30 passes for 273 yards and 4 touchdowns.
In 1993, Dallas finished 12–4, the best record in the NFC. In the playoffs, Aikman again guided Dallas to home playoff victory, this time over a young, upstart <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> squad led by quarterback <a href="Brett%20Favre">Brett Favre</a>, who was in his first full season as a starting quarterback. Aikman then shredded the 49ers secondary in the NFC Championship 38–21, before leaving the game with a concussion after 49ers defensive tackle <a href="Dana%20Stubblefield">Dana Stubblefield</a>'s knee hit Aikman's head. Aikman now says he has no memory of playing in the game. In <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXVIII">Super Bowl XXVIII</a>, Aikman was kept out of the end zone, but a combination of key turnovers by the Bills offense and the running of Emmitt Smith helped lead to a 30–13 victory for the Cowboys.
Head coach Jimmy Johnson left the team on March 29, 1994, and Jerry Jones hired <a href="Barry%20Switzer">Barry Switzer</a>, Aikman's former college coach at Oklahoma. The Cowboys finished with the second-best record in the NFC, (behind the 49ers) and Aikman again missed playing time due to injuries. Dallas won their Divisional Playoff game against Green Bay 35–9, but fell to the 49ers in the NFC Championship, 38–28.
In 1995, Aikman passed for over 3,300 yards as the Cowboys once again finished with the best record in the NFC, with the 49ers having the second-best record. Aikman was knocked out of a highly anticipated rematch between Dallas and San Francisco when 49ers' Stubblefield landed on Aikman, forcing his knee to hit the turf. After a playoff loss at home by the 49ers to the Packers, the Cowboys hosted the Packers in the NFC Championship and, for the third straight season, knocked the Packers out of the playoffs, this time by a 38–27 score, to earn their third Super Bowl appearance in four years. Dallas won <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXX">Super Bowl XXX</a> against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> 27–17, with Aikman throwing one touchdown pass.
In 1996, despite offensive troubles, Aikman again helped lead Dallas to another NFC East Division title and a home game for the Wild Card playoff round, a 40–15 drubbing of the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>. The following week, Dallas fell in the Divisional Playoffs to Carolina, 26–17.
In 1997, Aikman became the first quarterback in Cowboys' history to have three straight 3,000-yard seasons, but the team finished 6–10 and missed the playoffs for the first time since 1990. Switzer suffered the first losing season of his career, and resigned at the end of the season.
1998 was a rebound year for Aikman and Cowboys, and despite missing five games, Aikman again helped lead Dallas back to the NFC East title and the playoffs. Dallas was stunned at home in the Wild Card game as the #6 seed <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a> won, 20–7.
The 1999 season started off with a bang for Aikman and the Cowboys as they squared off against the Redskins. Aikman fired a career-high five touchdown passes, including the game winner in overtime to beat Washington. 1999 also marked the final playoff appearance for Aikman, and the final season the trio of Aikman, Irvin and Emmitt Smith would play together. Dallas finished 8–8 and lost in the Wild Card playoff game at Minnesota, 27–10.
The 2000 season was Aikman's final season as a professional football player. Aikman suffered from several concussions during the season, and a revolving door at quarterback took place between Aikman and former Eagles quarterback <a href="Randall%20Cunningham">Randall Cunningham</a>. Aikman's final game was at home against the Washington Redskins. He was hit by <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> <a href="LaVar%20Arrington">LaVar Arrington</a> and suffered the tenth and final concussion of his career.
During the 2001 offseason, Aikman was waived a day before he was due a $70 million/7-year contract extension, and ultimately announced his retirement on April 9, after failing to find another team. He ended his career as the Cowboys' all-time leading passer (32,942 yards). 90 of his <a href="Most%20wins%20by%20a%20starting%20quarterback%20%28NFL%29">94 career wins</a> were in the 1990s and were the most by any quarterback in any decade until <a href="Peyton%20Manning">Peyton Manning</a> surpassed him in the 2000s with 115 wins. Presently, Aikman is third on that list, also trailing <a href="Tom%20Brady">Tom Brady</a> (122 in the 2010s).
During a late December 2013 radio interview, Aikman said the real reason he retired was due to persistent back issues he had in his final season. Aikman explained that he had back surgery in the offseason following Super Bowl XXVII with no complications but by the time he reached his final season he was constantly getting treatment for back pain. While the hit by Arrington ended his 2000 season, he claims it was the back pain and not that concussion that ended his career. In a January 2020 interview, Aikman said he wanted to sign with the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a> after being released by the Cowboys in the 2001 offseason to play for <a href="Norv%20Turner">Norv Turner</a>, but they signed <a href="Doug%20Flutie">Doug Flutie</a> instead and Aikman chose to retire. He said <a href="Andy%20Reid">Andy Reid</a> called him after Eagles' starting quarterback <a href="Donovan%20McNabb">Donovan McNabb</a> suffered a broken ankle in week 11 of the <a href="2002%20NFL%20season">2002 season</a> to offer him the starting position, but Aikman declined. In 2003, Aikman agreed to play for the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> with Turner as their offensive coordinator and began training again, but the team decided against signing him to a contract.
Post-retirement activities.
After his retirement from professional football as a player, Aikman joined Fox's <a href="National%20Football%20Conference">NFC</a> telecasts as a <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a> for the 2001 season. A year later, he was named to the network's lead announcing crew, teaming with <a href="Joe%20Buck">Joe Buck</a> and (from 2002 to 2004) <a href="Cris%20Collinsworth">Cris Collinsworth</a>. Aikman received an <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a> nomination for his television work in 2004 and has helped broadcast six <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>s (<a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXIX">XXXIX</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLII">XLII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLV">XLV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVIII">XLVIII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LI">LI</a>, and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LIV">LIV</a>) to date. It was revealed in 2016 that in 2004, Aikman nearly came out of retirement to sign a one-year deal with the Miami Dolphins but the Dolphins ended up not signing him.
Aikman also hosts a weekly <a href="sports%20radio">sports radio</a> show which airs on Thursday from 7 to 8 p.m. ET on <a href="Sporting%20News%20Radio">Sporting News Radio</a>, and appears weekly during the football season on the "Dunham & Miller" morning show on Dallas sports talk radio station <a href="KTCK%20%28AM%29">1310 The Ticket</a>. He was a public spokesman for <a href="Acme%20Brick">Acme Brick</a> throughout his career. He is also the chairman of the Troy Aikman Foundation, a charity to benefit children that has recently focused on building playplaces for <a href="children%27s%20hospital">children's hospital</a>s. <a href="http%3A//www.theagencysports.com">The Agency Sports Management & Marketing</a> handles Aikman's marketing activities, where Jordan Bazant is his lead agent.
Aikman, who in 1999 was ranked No. 95 on "<a href="The%20Sporting%20News">The Sporting News</a>"' list of the 100 Greatest Football Players, has been the official <a href="Wing%20Stop%20Restaurants">Wing Stop</a> spokesman for several years. He appeared in the Simpsons episode "Sunday, Cruddy Sunday" alongside former <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> quarterback <a href="Dan%20Marino">Dan Marino</a>. He also participated in the 2001 and 2011 videos honoring <a href="Billy%20Graham">Billy Graham</a>'s 83rd and 93rd birthdays. Aikman said he was going to appear in <a href="Dancing%20with%20the%20Stars">Dancing with the Stars</a> in front of TMZ cameras. However, he revealed he was only joking about it and won't appear on the show.
On September 19, 2005, at halftime of the Cowboys-Redskins game (broadcast on "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>"), Aikman was inducted into the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys%20Ring%20of%20Honor">Dallas Cowboys Ring of Honor</a> with his longtime teammates <a href="Michael%20Irvin">Michael Irvin</a> and <a href="Emmitt%20Smith">Emmitt Smith</a>. On August 5, 2006, Aikman was one of six players inducted into the <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>.
At another halftime ceremony, this one on February 7, 2009, at the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20UCLA%20Bruins%20men%27s%20basketball%20team%23Highlights">UCLA-Notre Dame basketball game</a>, Aikman's induction into the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Hall of Fame</a> was honored. Aikman announced he had completed course work to finish his degree in sociology. He participated in UCLA's 2009 Sociology Department commencement ceremony with current quarterback <a href="Kevin%20Craft">Kevin Craft</a> and former linebacker Marcus Reece, who also came back to finish his college education. Former UCLA quarterback <a href="John%20Sciarra">John Sciarra</a> was keynote speaker at the ceremony.
On February 9, 2010, Aikman became a member of the <a href="National%20Football%20Foundation">National Football Foundation</a> Board of Directors.
As of fall 2010, Aikman is a co-spokesman for Rent-a-Center, along with <a href="Hulk%20Hogan">Hulk Hogan</a>.
In fall 2011, Aikman became a part of the Oxford Preparatory Academy Charter School Advisory Board in Southern California.
In November 2013, Aikman was named as a 2014 recipient of the NCAA <a href="Silver%20Anniversary%20Awards%20%28NCAA%29">Silver Anniversary Award</a>, given annually to six former college athletes 25 years after the end of their college athletics careers.
In March 2014, Aikman was announced as a partner and spokesman for IDLife.
Prior to a 2020 NFL broadcast between the <a href="2020%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Packers</a> and <a href="2020%20Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers%20season">Buccaneers</a> in <a href="Tampa">Tampa</a>, Aikman and his partner <a href="Joe%20Buck">Joe Buck</a> were caught on a hot mic questioning the necessity of a military flyover when only 15,000 fans were allowed in <a href="Raymond%20James%20Stadium">Raymond James Stadium</a> for the game. Aikman most notably said "That's a lot of jet fuel just to do a little flyover" and "That stuff ain't happening with a Kamala-Biden ticket, I'll tell you that right now, partner." An Armed Forces spokesperson later said there is no additional cost to conduct the flyovers. Meanwhile, Buck and Aikman faced accusations of being unpatriotic.
Hall of Fame Racing.
In late 2005, Aikman together with another former Cowboys quarterback, <a href="Roger%20Staubach">Roger Staubach</a>, established <a href="Hall%20of%20Fame%20Racing">Hall of Fame Racing</a> with <a href="Terry%20Labonte">Terry Labonte</a> and <a href="Tony%20Raines">Tony Raines</a> co-driving the #96 DLP HDTV Chevrolet in the NASCAR NEXTEL Cup Series in 2006 (the race car's number was derived by multiplying Aikman's Cowboy jersey number 8 by Staubach's jersey number 12). Raines drove for Aikman full-time in 2007, and <a href="J.J.%20Yeley">J.J. Yeley</a> and <a href="Brad%20Coleman">Brad Coleman</a> drove the car in 2008. He has invited some of the current and former Dallas Cowboys players <a href="Drew%20Bledsoe">Drew Bledsoe</a>, <a href="Terry%20Glenn">Terry Glenn</a>, <a href="Roy%20Williams%20%28safety%29">Roy Williams</a>, and others to test drive NASCAR race cars at Texas Motor Speedway.
Personal life.
Aikman, once named the most eligible bachelor in Dallas by "Texas Monthly", dated country singer <a href="Lorrie%20Morgan">Lorrie Morgan</a>. He married former Cowboys publicist Rhonda Worthey on April 8, 2000, in Plano, Texas. Worthey has a daughter from a previous marriage, named Rachel. Worthey and Aikman have two daughters. The couple announced their separation on January 24, 2011. Their divorce became final April 12, 2011. On June 2, 2017, Aikman announced his engagement to high-end fashion retailer Catherine "Capa" Mooty on Instagram. Mooty has two sons by her ex-husband, lawyer Jerry Mooty, who is the nephew of Cowboys' owner Jerry Jones. On September 1, 2017, Troy Aikman and Catherine Mooty married at the Biltmore Four Seasons in <a href="Montecito%2C%20California">Montecito</a>, California.
